# Assessment Criteria

## Components (1)

:::{.incremental}
- **Final Exam** 
  - 40%
  - Cheat Sheet allowed (details to follow)
- **Project Submission**
   - 30% 
   - To be conducted alone or in pairs
   - [**Goal**]{.col1}: Apply econometric methods by conducting a research project from start to finish for the first time
   - Can continue an Econometrics II project, if you did one
   - Can serve as inspiration for the bachelor thesis
:::

## Components (2)

:::{.incremental}
- **Project Presentation**
   - 20% 
   - Presentation of your project submission, thus in the same groups
   - About 20 minutes, with questions allowed throughout and no separate discussion (details to follow)
- **Active Participation**
  - 10%
  - To get full points, you must actively participate in at least 4 lectures (lectures end before the exam). 
  - [**Attendance**]{.col1} ≠ [**Participation**]{.col2} 
:::                                   


## Grading Scheme

. . .

- The components are **weighted** as outlined above. The final grade is then determined by the following scale:

| Grade |                | from   | to      |
|-------|----------------|:------:|:-------:|
| 1     | Excellent      | 87.5 % |         |
| 2     | Good           | 75.0 % | < 87.5 %|
| 3     | Satisfactory   | 62.5 % | < 75.0 %|
| 4     | Sufficient     | 50.0 % | < 62.5 %|
| 5     | Fail           |        | < 50.0 %|

: {.striped .noborder}

. . .

- **No rounding** is applied.

# Statistical Software

## R, Stata, Python 

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="70%"}
<ul>
  <li class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1">For your project, you will need to <strong>apply</strong> what we have learned using real data.</li>
  <li class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2">You might also work with data in the <strong>future</strong>.</li>
  <li class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3">
    You are generally free to choose which <strong>software</strong> you use to complete the tasks, as you will be in real life (results should be more or less the same):
    <ul>
      <li class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4"><strong>R</strong> is widely used, open source, and free. Code examples in this course are provided in R.</li>
      <li class="fragment" data-fragment-index="5"><strong>Stata</strong> is proprietary but preferred by some economists.</li>
      <li class="fragment" data-fragment-index="6"><strong>Python</strong></li>
      <li class="fragment" data-fragment-index="7"><strong>Eviews</strong></li>
      <li class="fragment" data-fragment-index="8"><strong>Julia</strong></li>
      <li class="fragment" data-fragment-index="9"><strong>Microsoft Excel</strong> (just don't)</li>
    </ul>
  </li>
</ul>
